TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is the editor of the political satirical periodical " ORG Poplu " ( NOT in the people ’s interest ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE an article entitled " Mix - Xena tax - Xandir " ( From ORG ) appeared in the applicant ’s periodical commenting on a particular parliamentary debate in ORG , which had been broadcast live on television . The article included the following passages :
" SEND IN THE CLOWN

Some felt offended that I had lately written that , during the budget debates , I went berserk and started throwing tomatoes at the television set . And this happened when certain Members of ORG had not as yet spoken in the debates . I will let your fertile imagination take its course to imagine what I did when CARDINAL of them in particular were speaking .
THE PARLIAMENTARY CLOWN

I do not know if I shall be in breach of LAW if I describe a minister as a clown . But I can not fail to comment on PERSON behaviour in ORG . It seems that PERSON deliberately tried to make us laugh . If this is so , PERSON is ridiculing what is supposed to be the highest institution of the land .

Let us see what PERSON was up to . His first sentence was meant to raise some laughs as he maintained that PERSON , a NORP Member of ORG , badly needed a pair of spectacles . This was rather a flat joke . Then he started calling names PERSON [ a NORP Member of ORG ] and described the latter as a man who lacked principles . Then he tried to make us laugh once again when he referred to the killing of pigs . Anyway , he tried to play the clown once , twice and even CARDINAL times . And some of his jokes were rather vulgar .

I felt extremely angry that the man who is representing the people , and that includes yours truly , on agricultural matters , was using this serious and important debate to play the clown . Well , I thought , if PERSON has the right to speak the way he likes on the television screen , in my home , then I am also entitled to speak my mind . And I started booing him with all my might , and had I had enough tomatoes , I would have used them for other purposes .

You may ask me what I did when ‘ il - Profs’ PERSON of Cospicua took the microphone . First and foremost , this man is not as yet aware that PERSON has resigned and PERSON still echoes him to DATE . Secondly , you stand no chance of finding anything worthwhile after analysing PERSON ’s speech . At least , you may find something worthwhile in PERSON speech , but you discover absolutely nothing in PERSON ’s . Let me tell you what I did when this professor stood up to speak .

I booed this last one so heartily that the neighbours thought that I had had an epileptic fit . To crown it all , PERSON , that nosy PERSON , entered my home unannounced and without permission and she found me on the floor in an ecstasy of booing . She thought I had become a lunatic . Really , the scene in front of the television was scary . PERSON was gesticulating and talking rubbish on ORG set while I lay sprawled on the floor gesticulating like a madman . And I did all this so that I may have enough material for ‘ MHUX’ . To persuade PERSON that nothing was really wrong with me I had to allow her to take my pulse rate , examine my tongue and take my temperature . "

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON and PERSON , CARDINAL of the Members of ORG referred to , brought the article to the attention of ORG as an alleged breach of privilege . On DATE , before the applicant had been heard , the Speaker announced that he had examined the matter and found a prima facie case of breach of privilege . The ORG , on a proposal by Mr PERSON , proceeded on DATE to pass a resolution which stated that the ORG considered the article in question as a breach of its privileges according to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) of ORG ) Ordinance ( LAW the Revised Edition of the Laws of Malta ; see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , hereinafter referred to as " the Ordinance " .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG considered a motion , proposed by PERSON and seconded by Mr PERSON , to direct the applicant to be summoned by notice LAW ) of the LAW to answer a charge of defamatory libel under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) of the Ordinance . The terms of the motion were :

" That the ORG after having by its own resolution decided in the sitting of CARDINAL DATE that the article bearing the title ‘ Mix - Xena tax - Xandir’ which appeared at page CARDINAL of the ‘ ORG of DATE be considered a breach of privilege according to section CARDINAL ) of ORG ) Ordinance ;

The ORG orders GPE ORG , ORG , ORG , PERSON , as editor of the journal ‘ ORG , to appear before it in the sitting of CARDINAL DATE at TIME to state why he should not be found guilty of breach of privilege according to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) of ORG ) Ordinance ; and
The ORG also orders the subpoena of every witness that ORG will be asked to summon . "

The then Leader of the Opposition , Dr PERSON , drew attention to the wording of the resolution of DATE which he considered out of order since it did not make it clear that there was only a prima facie case of breach of privilege . For his part , PERSON expressed the opinion that the proposed motion did not state that the applicant was guilty :

" Here we are not saying that he is guilty . We are saying : Come here so that on DATE you will say why you are not guilty . And if ever you were to convince us that you are not guilty we will say that you are not guilty ; if you will not convince us we will say you are guilty . "
After the debate the motion was adopted as proposed by PERSON .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr GPE brought an application before ORG of GPE in exercise of its constitutional jurisdiction challenging the proceedings instituted against him by ORG on the ground that these proceedings , which were penal in nature , violated his right under section CARDINAL of the LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) to be given a fair hearing by an independent and impartial court .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL , DATE and DATE , before the delivery of the judgment of ORG , the applicant appeared before ORG with his lawyer .

It was submitted as a point of order that further proceedings on the case in the ORG should be suspended until the court had determined the constitutional issue , but the Speaker ruled that the ORG should proceed with the case before it . The question was then put to the applicant , " Does the editor consider himself to be guilty or not please ? Mr GPE , do you consider yourself guilty ? " When the applicant refused to answer whether he was guilty or not , he was threatened with further proceedings for contempt . CARDINAL of the members of the ORG , Dr PERSON , stated on a point of order that the breach of privilege proceedings were to be considered as being of a criminal nature and accordingly - an argument accepted by the Speaker - the rule of criminal procedure that he who stands mute is presumed to have answered ‘ not guilty’ should be applied .

PERSON proceeded to adduce the evidence against the applicant , reading out the impugned article and concluding that it insulted Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON in connection with their conduct in the ORG . The latter were invited by the Speaker to comment and both made statements to the effect that they considered themselves ridiculed in their capacity as members of the ORG , as well as in their private lives .
Mr PERSON subsequently said ,

" Mr Speaker , this is the last time I come here and go to ORG in connection with this dirt . And if they attack me personally I will neither seek redress here nor go to court . Okay ? And if trouble crops up in my family , if you [ pointing to defence lawyer ] defend him [ the applicant ] , I will [ ‘ sue you’ ( according to the ORG ’s translation ) ] [ ‘ take my revenge on DATE ( according to the applicant ’s translation ) ] . "
On DATE the ORG adopted a resolution in the following terms :
" That the ORG after having considered the case of breach of its privileges caused by the article published at page CARDINAL of the journal ‘ ORG Number CARDINAL of DATE ;
Finds the editor PERSON guilty of breach of privilege . "
The ORG postponed the question of punishment until another sitting , due , according to the Government , to the pending constitutional proceedings .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG delivered judgment in favour of the applicant . It began by finding that the proceedings were not criminal in nature :

" ORG is not an ordinary court , although , because of the system of checks and balances already referred to , it also has quasi - judicial functions , apart from its principal function of legislator . And the law that provides for the privileges and contempt of the ORG ( chapter CARDINAL ) is not part of the criminal law of the country . It is true , as argued by the applicant , that there is a great resemblance between the penalties provided for by LAW and those provided for by this particular law . However , the decision of the ORG is not the criminal conviction that emerges from a decision of ORG , and the declaration of guilt for contempt and the consequential sanctions from such a declaration , despite having the same form as criminal penalties - admonitions , payment of money , imprisonment - are nonetheless not criminal convictions . "
However , the ORG continued :
" The ORG may take proceedings for contempt where , among other things , there results :
‘ ( k ) the publication of any defamatory libel on the Speaker or any Member touching anything done or said by him as Speaker or as a Member in the ORG or in LOC ( Vide sect . CARDINAL LAW ) .

For the ORG to have jurisdiction to take proceedings for contempt there must be a defamatory libel ( a mixed question of fact and law ) and the law did not state that this is a question that must be established by the ORG , but something that must exist objectively ; this being so , the declaration of the existence of the defamatory libel must first be made objectively by the ORG , and then there will be proceedings in the ORG for contempt . "

ORG concluded that the Ordinance in question did not authorise ORG of its own initiative to define what is a defamatory libel , and that , if and when it acts upon a contempt , it must act according to the principles of natural justice . It ordered that the applicant be placed in the position in which he was before proceedings were instituted against him on the basis of breach of privilege and that no further proceedings be taken against him on the basis of the resolution and motion in question .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , on appeal by both parties , disagreed with the conclusions of ORG . It held that the LAW authorised ORG to enact laws establishing its privileges , immunities and powers , that accordingly the powers given to the ORG by virtue of LAW of LAW did not violate the person ’s right to a fair hearing by an independent court as guaranteed under section CARDINAL of the LAW and that in those circumstances the lower court had not been entitled to look further into the matter or to afford the remedies indicated in its judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG summoned the applicant before it in order to decide the penalty to be imposed upon him . On being asked if he wished to comment , the applicant stated through his lawyer that he had nothing to say regarding the punishment but would comply with the ORG ’s decision . He was fined CARDINAL NORP liri and ordered to publish the resolution of CARDINAL March CARDINAL in his paper .
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON participated throughout in the proceedings brought against the applicant , save that Mr PERSON died before the sitting of CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . The applicant has not as yet paid the fine and no steps have been taken to enforce its recovery .
CARDINAL . As applicable at the relevant time , the provisions of the LAW concerning the privileges of ORG were as follows :

" An oath or affirmation taken or made by a witness or by an expert before ORG or any ORG thereof shall for the purposes of LAW ( LAW ) be comparable to an oath or affirmation taken or made before a ORG in civil matters . "

" ( CARDINAL ) The ORG shall have the power to punish with a reprimand or with imprisonment for a period not exceeding DATE or with a fine not exceeding MONEY or with both such fine and such imprisonment , any person , whether a Member of the ORG or not , guilty of any of the following acts :
( k ) the publication of any defamatory libel on the Speaker or any Member touching anything done or said by him as Speaker or as a Member in the ORG or in a ORG thereof ;

( CARDINAL ) For the purposes of this section - ‘ publication’ means any act whereby any printed matter is or may be communicated to or brought to the knowledge of any person or whereby any words or visual images are broadcast ; ...

( CARDINAL ) A person shall be deemed guilty of the acts mentioned in PERSON ] ( k ) ... of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of this section if the publication referred to in PERSON ] ( k ) ... consists in the publication of such defamatory libel , false or perverted report , or misrepresentation in printed form in GPE , or in the distribution in GPE of such printed matter containing such defamatory libel , false or perverted report , or misrepresentation , from whatsoever place such printed matter may originate , or in any broadcast from any place in GPE or any place outside GPE of any such defamatory libel , false or perverted report , or misrepresentation . "

Subsection ( CARDINAL ) entitles the ORG to order in the case of a newspaper , in addition to the punishments under subsection ( CARDINAL ) , the publication in a subsequent issue of the motion finding the accused guilty of an act mentioned in paragraph ( k ) of subsection ( CARDINAL ) .
" ( CARDINAL ) ...
( CARDINAL ) ... the ORG may direct the offender to be summoned by notice signed by ORG , to appear before it at a specified sitting to answer the charge .
( CARDINAL ) If the offender fails to appear , it shall be lawful for the Speaker of the ORG on the direction thereof , to issue a warrant for the offender to be arrested and brought before the ORG .
( CARDINAL ) In all cases the offender shall be given the opportunity to speak in his own defence and , ... , he may be assisted by an advocate .
" ( CARDINAL ) ...

( CARDINAL ) When the ORG fines a person , the fine shall be paid to ORG through ORG within DATE of its infliction . At the next following sitting the Clerk shall report to the Speaker the payment so made or its default ; in the latter case the ORG may decide on the commutation of the fine into a term of imprisonment or give other directions at its discretion . "
CARDINAL . Defamatory libel is a criminal offence under LAW ( Act No . XL of DATE ) .

" The offences mentioned in this Part of the LAW are committed by means of the publication or distribution in GPE of printed matter , from whatsoever place such matter may originate , or by means of any broadcast . "
" Save as otherwise provided in this LAW , whosoever shall , by any means mentioned in LAW , libel any person , shall be liable on conviction :

( a ) if the libel contains specific imputations against such person tending to injure his character and reputation , or to expose him to public ridicule or contempt , to imprisonment for a term not exceeding DATE or to a fine ( multa ) not exceeding MONEY or to both such imprisonment and fine ;
( b ) in any other case , to imprisonment for a term not exceeding DATE or to a fine . "
CARDINAL . The LAW of GPE also refers to the privileges of ORG .

Under section CARDINAL no person is to be deprived of his personal liberty save as may be authorised by law , inter alia , in execution of an order of ORG punishing him for contempt of itself or of its members or for breach of privilege , or directing that he be brought before it .
Section CARDINAL provides for any person charged with a criminal offence to be afforded a fair hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial court established by law .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) guarantees freedom of expression with the following proviso under subsection ( CARDINAL ) :

" Nothing contained in or done under the authority of any law shall be held to be inconsistent with or in contravention of subsection ( CARDINAL ) of this section to the extent that the law in question makes provision -
( a ) that is reasonably required -
( i ) in the interests of defence , public order , public morality or decency , or public health ; or
( ii ) for the purpose of [ ... ] protecting the privileges of ORG [ ... ]
